_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Fill alarm at 80% with auto. Shutoff at 85%, min. class 1 Div. 1 electric w/in 5 ft. of all transfer (truck offloading) points w/Class 1 Div. 2 from 5-15 feet, Class 1 Div. 2 w/in 15 ft. of remainder
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Hydrocarbon detectors, flow monitoring, temperature, pressure & liquid level indicators
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Monthly Preventative Maintenance (LEL calibration. pump inspection, etc.)
_prev_prog_3.Description: Butane (2x90,000 gallons plus lines, liquefied and stored under pressure), blending system involving direct injection into refined product (gasoline) pipelines with bulk truck offloading.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Kinder Morgan Southeast Terminals, LLC (KMST) - North Augusta #2 Terminal is a bulk petroleum storage and distribution facility that includes butane blending operations. This Risk Management Plan (RMP) covers the Butane Blending System, including the associated piping and two 90,000 gallon butane storage vessels. KMST owns the real property associated with the Butane Blending System.  Energy Transfer (ET) owns all the equipment associated with the Butane Blending System.  ET and KMST each have operational responsibilities for the Butane Blending System. ET controls and monitors all butane blending operations remotely from its control center located near Houston, Texas, conducts all maintenance activities, and schedules the delivery of butane trucks. KMST oversees the unloading of butane trucks into both storage vessels and conducts routine visual inspections.



ET constructed the Butane Blending System in accordance with the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA Code) No. 58 (2011 Edition) for Liquefied Petroleum Gas Storage. ET designed, constructed, and maintains the Butane Blending System, in accordance with NFPA No. 58 and the manufacturer's instructions and recommendations.



It is the Parties' policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws/codes. If an emergency were to occur, it is the Parties' policy to notify the Belvedere Fire Department as well as the South Carolina Department of Emergency Management. Medical emergencies will require notification of the local Emergency Management Services and the University Hospital, Augusta, Georgia, which is the nearest full service hospital/emergency department.



The Parties comply with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Accident Prevention Rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D), the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and associated 14 elements (29 CFR Part 1910.119), and all applicable state and local laws and regulations. T

his facility has not had an accident involving butane which has resulted in deaths, injuries, property/environmental damage, evacuations or sheltering in place.



In the event of an emergency involving the Butane Blending System, it is the Parties' policy to initially contact the owner of the equipment - ET and the local fire department. The facility emergency response plans are coordinated with the local fire department. The Belvedere Fire Department personnel have participated in the initial RMP/PSM training session for this system.



Process safety controls include excess flow valves, low-melting point pneumatic valve feeds top pneumatic valves (fail closed), 85% fill shut-off (80% alarm and 90% ESD actuation) on the vessels, emergency shut-off devices on the system and video display terminal, line thermal/hydrostatic reliefs, and grounding interlock devices. Additional vessel protection includes an intumescent coating. Note: In contrast to the PSM requirements, this "stationary source" as defined under 40 CFR Part 68 is bounded by the off-load station and the points of injection.



The Parties actively seek employee input on process safety improvements. Additionally, the Belvedere Fire Department is contacted regarding participation in site emergency response drills.  Additional actions include consolidating separate system inspection checklists for ease of completion.
